entry.title: Twitter 已开始向选定的“创作者”群体支付报酬
entry.content:
推特：

要被视为有资格获得创作者广告收入分成，您必须：

  1. 订阅 Twitter Blue 或经过验证的组织
  2. 过去 3 个月内，您的帖子每年至少获得 500 万次展示。
  3. 通过创作者获利​​标准的人工审核。

这个想法是，这将把 Twitter 变成一个类似 YouTube 的高调账户平台。不过，目前看来这可能是一场骗局——没有公开招募，而且现在获得报酬的人似乎是埃隆·马斯克(Elon Musk)亲手挑选的。 泰勒·洛伦兹（Taylor Lorenz）为《华盛顿邮报》撰文：

从事以创作者为中心的产品工作的前 Twitter 员工对此次推出表示怀疑，其中一些人称其为公关噱头。一位负责创作者合作关系的 Twitter 前高管表示，“我们过去所做的任何内容货币化都是基于收入模式。为了避免遭到报复，他要求匿名。对于他想要安抚的特定创作者来说，这感觉是凭空而来的。”

这位前 Twitter 高管还对 Twitter 修改后的指标（包括印象数）表示怀疑。 “这些数字完全是假的。这一切都是完全编造出来的。感觉就像他们随意给自己喜欢的人开支票，这不是可持续的创作者策略。”

值得对匿名“前 Twitter 员工”的言论持保留态度（或许，对 Lorenz 的署名也持保留态​​度），但对 Twitter 的新举措也值得持保留态度。我真的怀疑这是否能持续下去。不过，如果有人最终能够宣称自己是一名专业的高音扬声器，那就太棒了。

★

entry.title: 贝尔实验室霍姆德尔综合体
entry.content:
马修·克里斯托弗在《被遗弃的美国》中：

位于新泽西州霍姆德尔的贝尔实验室霍姆德尔综合体是贝尔电话公司决定将业务迁出曼哈顿时创建的新研发设施。它建于 1959 年至 1962 年间，是建筑师埃罗·沙里宁 (Eero Saarinen) 的绝唱，他还设计了圣路易斯拱门和约翰·F·肯尼迪国际中心的环球航空飞行中心。萨里宁在 Holmdel 竣工前一年去世，距离这座六层建筑群被《研发杂志》评为年度实验室还有六年。镜面玻璃外幕墙允许 25% 的太阳光进入，同时阻挡 70% 的热量，这使得 Holmdel 综合体被建筑论坛命名为“有史以来最大的镜子”，并且该综合体被大学用作现代主义建筑风格的最高成就之一。 [...]

在贝尔实验室翻修开始前不久，建筑师亚历山大·戈尔林允许我拍摄贝尔实验室的照片。大部分内部空间已被剥离，只剩下基本元素，中庭的植物也消失了，但建筑仍然令人着迷。很多年前，这座建筑开放时我曾参观过，但现在对我来说却很陌生。许多房间在里面的所有东西都被移走后完全是匿名的。

《Severance》的粉丝们会立即认出那个令人惊叹的中庭——这座建筑是 Lumon Industries 总部的所在地。

entry.title: “电动自行车，我一生的愚蠢之爱”
entry.content:
克雷格·莫德：

我很早就认为，如果世界上每个人都买一辆自行车，就可以实现世界和平，但现在我希望这些自行车是电动的。我希望每个人都能感受到这种愚蠢，这种纯粹的爱的醉酒愚蠢，这种欺骗规则、规范的感觉，这种永远存在的快乐感。在最糟糕的情况下，人类会盲目地消费，烧焦大地和彼此，让我们的身体充满毒药。我们竭尽全力发明电动自行车。电池变得更加高效，电机变得更小、更强大。过去十年为这些机器带来了巨大的效率，而未来十年这些收益只会加倍。电动自行车的数量逐年增加。非常如此。那些知道的人，劝说他们。我们无能为力。魅力太大了。博弈非零和。知道的人越多，世界就越好。这是一个疯狂的想法，只要你伸手去争取，就会有这种美好的感觉。善良，没有真正的缺点。就像太阳能电池板或风力涡轮机一样，电动自行车是支撑精神和地球的机器。

多么可爱的文章啊。很难阅读它，并且无法立即打开浏览器选项卡来开始购买电动自行车。

entry.title: 截止日期：“好莱坞制片厂”WGA 罢工最终结果是让编剧们在秋季恢复谈判之前破产”
entry.content:
Dominic Patten，两天前为 Deadline 报道：

“我认为我们将面临一场长期的罢工，而他们将会让它流血，”一位熟悉工作室首席执行官观点的业内资深人士表示。抄写员罢工现已结束第 71 天，而演员工会距离可能举行的罢工仅 30 小时，电影和电视制片人联盟计划在今年秋天全力以赴，然后再考虑更多的想法。我在与 WGA 的谈话中得知。一位与卡罗尔·隆巴迪尼 (Carol Lombardini) 经营的 AMPTP 关系密切的顶级制片人表示：“确切地说，我们的目的不是万圣节，而是十月下旬。” [...]

自 WGA 5 月 2 日罢工以来，华纳兄弟探索频道、苹果、Netflix、亚马逊、迪士尼、派拉蒙等公司收到了华尔街的积极反馈，正如一位制片厂高管公然指出的那样，他们决心“打破 WGA”。为了做到这一点，制片厂和 AMPTP 相信，到 10 月，大多数作家在纠察线上五个月没有工作后，就会耗尽资金。

一位工作室高管告诉 Deadline：“最终的结果是让事情一直拖下去，直到工会成员开始失去他们的公寓和房子。”其他几位消息人士承认这种冷漠的态度，也重申了这一说法。一位内部人士称其为“残酷但必要的罪恶”。

确实冷如冰。在任何领域，很少有人能连续几个月没有薪水。

自从 1960 年玛丽莲·梦露还在主演电影以来，演员和编剧同时罢工的时间就更长了。双重罢工让超过 17 万名员工与迪士尼、环球、索尼和派拉蒙等老牌电影公司以及 Netflix、亚马逊和苹果等新兴巨头展开斗争。

entry.title: “主力酿造是旧金山”
entry.content:
帕特里克·雷德福（Patrick Redford）为《叛逃者》撰文：

人们很容易将其视为另一个关于流行病夺走一项受人喜爱的业务的严峻故事，因为 Anchor 已成为旧金山的代名词，因此增添了一点世界末日的气息。从这个角度来看，这座城市最具标志性的公司之一的死亡与这样一种说法密切相关：旧金山是一座垂死的城市，被不受控制的犯罪、不断上升的负担能力以及呃，觉醒的三重祸害撕裂。即使你不想走那么远，你也可以将旧金山的高办公空间空置率、 全国精酿啤酒销量下降和“通货膨胀”联系起来，并得出这样的结论：这种经济环境对 Anchor 来说太严峻了，无法生存。在这种情况下，小企业怎么能继续营业呢？这就是札幌的公关暴徒正在兜售的故事，而《旧金山纪事报》正在购买的故事，没有任何阻力或工人的观点，尽管这不是事实。经济状况很重要，尽管它们与 Anchor 故事的相关性不如札幌独特的灾难性的公司管理。

一个美好的回忆，充满了进一步阅读的重要链接，包括大卫·伯克哈特（David Burkhart）去年刚刚出版的书《锚酿造故事》（The Anchor Brewing Story）的摘录。

我想到的是，小规模的卓越是微妙而珍贵的。当 Anchor 的啤酒仍然像以前一样受欢迎时，他们可能会亏损，这似乎是不可思议的，但把它留给像札幌这样的大企业集团，以做大事情的名义来储存一个好的小东西。

★

entry.title: 拥有 127 年历史的 Anchor Brewing 即将停业
entry.content:
Jess Lander 和 Caleb Pershan 为《旧金山纪事报》报道了悲伤的消息：

蒸汽啤酒之父、旧金山机构 Anchor Brewing Co. 在运营 127 年后即将倒闭。 Anchor 发言人 Sam Singer 表示，该啤酒厂“每年损失数百万美元”。 “经济压力使业务不再可持续。”

Anchor 已经在历史悠久的 Potrero Hill 啤酒厂酿造了最后一杯啤酒——“现在啤酒厂已经没有蒸汽了，”Singer 说——并在周三凌晨通知了啤酒厂的 61 名员工关闭的消息。啤酒厂的酒吧 Anchor Public Taps 将至少持续运营到 8 月 1 日，甚至可能更久。

这一消息是在 Anchor 宣布停止全国分销并停止其自 1975 年以来一直生产的深受喜爱的圣诞啤酒一个月后发布的。据 Singer 称，当日本啤酒巨头札幌于 2017 年收购 Anchor 时，该公司已经“亏损”他表示，自 2016 年以来，收入下降了三分之二。辛格补充道，此次疫情对这家啤酒厂来说尤其具有挑战性，因为该公司通常通过酒吧和餐馆销售大部分啤酒。他表示，该啤酒厂试图扩大零售分销，但“无法取得足够大的突破”。

真丢脸。 “喝当地的饮料”总是个好建议，旧金山的 Anchor Steam 总是很美味。不过，我不知道他们为什么要在全国范围内销售 Anchor Steam——这是我喝过的最糟糕的旅行啤酒之一。本地新鲜：美味。用卡车运到东海岸：嗯。在我在旧金山尝试之前，我一直想知道有什么大惊小怪的。

当他们推出荒谬的重新设计时，我就知道出了问题。不管出了什么问题，这肯定不是他们独特的品牌包装。

★

微信在中国的“一切应用”主导地位在中国是无与伦比的。

entry.title: 法官驳回 FTC 禁令，微软 750 亿美元收购动视暴雪的交易进一步临近
entry.content:
Jordan Novet，CNBC 报道：

旧金山的一名联邦法官驳回了联邦贸易委员会提出的初步禁令动议，以阻止微软完成对视频游戏发行商动视暴雪的收购。

不过，这笔交易尚未完全明朗。联邦贸易委员会现在可以将该决定提交给美国第九巡回上诉法院，两家公司必须找到解决英国竞争与市场管理局反对意见的方法。

完成交易的最后期限是下周，但市场预计它会发生：

在美国加州北区地方法院发布裁决后，动视暴雪股价创下盘中新高，并达到 52 周新高，每股 92.91 美元。微软同意以每股 95 美元的价格收购这家游戏发行商。动视暴雪股价周二收于每股 90.99 美元，上涨 10%。

这是拜登联邦贸易委员会的又一案例。至少可以说，微软是视频游戏领域的主要参与者，但 Xbox 是第三位的游戏机，微软做出了具有法律约束力的承诺，不仅将《使命召唤》在 PlayStation 上保留 10 年， 而且还将带来该系列游戏到任天堂开关。

★

似乎每家公司都在争先恐后地在人工智能淘金热中占据一席之地—— 克罗格的首席执行官承诺将法学硕士带入乳制品领域。一线工作人员也在效仿——尝试人工智能，以便他们可以更快地工作并做得更多。

自 ChatGPT 推出以来的短短几个月内，市场上已经出现了数百种人工智能驱动的工具。但是，虽然基于人工智能的工具具有真正有用的应用程序，但它们也带来了严重的安全风险。不幸的是，大多数公司仍然没有拿出管理这些风险的政策。在缺乏关于负责任的人工智能使用的明确指导的情况下，员工会漫不经心地将敏感数据交给不值得信赖的工具。

基于人工智能的浏览器扩展最清楚地说明了这一现象。 Chrome 商店中充斥着（声称）利用 ChatGPT 执行各种任务的扩展：发送电子邮件、设计图形、转录会议和编写代码。但这些工具容易出现至少三种类型的风险。

  1. 恶意软件：安全研究人员不断发现窃取用户数据的基于人工智能的扩展。这些扩展程序利用了用户对大型科技平台的信任（“如果 Google 允许它出现在 Chrome 商店中，那不会有危险！”），而且它们通常通过连接 ChatGPT 等人的 API 来发挥作用。
  2. 数据治理：包括苹果和威瑞森在内的公司已禁止其员工使用法学硕士，因为这些产品很少能保证用户的输入不会被用作培训数据。
  3. 即时注入攻击：在这种鲜为人知但可能无法解决的攻击中，网页上的隐藏文本指示人工智能工具执行恶意操作，例如窃取数据，然后删除记录。

到目前为止，大多数公司都被人工智能打了个措手不及，但这些风险太严重了，不容忽视。

在 Kolide，我们采用两部分方法来管理人工智能的使用。

  1. 以团队形式起草人工智能政策。我们不想完全禁止我们的团队使用人工智能，我们只是想安全地使用它。因此，我们的第一步是与多个团队的代表会面，了解他们从基于人工智能的工具中获得了什么，以及我们如何为他们提供不暴露关键数据或基础设施的安全选项。
  2. 使用 Kolide 阻止恶意工具。 Kolide 让 IT 和安全团队编写检测设备合规性问题的检查，我们已经开始为基于人工智能的恶意（或可疑）工具创建检查。现在，如果员工不小心下载了恶意软件，他们将无法登录我们的云应用程序，直到他们将其删除。

每家公司都必须根据自己独特的需求和关注点制定政策，但重要的是现在就开始。在人工智能卷走你公司的数据之前，我们还有时间抓住它的控制权。

entry.summary: 唉，这种情况已经成为一个反复出现的主题。现在是 Apollo，由 Christian Selig 精心制作的 Reddit 客户端。
entry.content:
今年早些时候，当 Twitter 毫不客气地终止第三方客户端时，Tweetbot 和 Twitterrific 等商业 Twitter 客户端陷入了危险的境地。 我写道：

Twitter 对第三方客户的打压不仅意味着他们未来的收入消失了，还意味着他们已经从 App Store 订阅中获得的收入需要以按比例退款的形式返还给客户。以及每个用户的年度订阅量。想想失去工作的严重打击——你停止赚取收入。太残酷了。现在想象一下，当您被解雇或解雇时，您也突然需要偿还最后（例如 6 个月）的收入。这就是 Tapbots 和 The Iconfactory 所在的地方。

我不记得这样的情况，第三方客户的生态系统收集订阅，然后让第一方服务在零警告或日落期的情况下从他们和他们的客户下面拉开地毯。

唉，这种情况已经成为一个反复出现的主题。现在是Apollo ，由 Christian Selig 精心制作的 Reddit 客户端。情况几乎相同：阿波罗本周早些时候停止工作，而塞利格则需要向年度订阅者退款数十万美元。

就像 Tweetbot 和 Twitterrific 一样，如果您是 Apollo 的订阅者，您可以采取以下措施来支持 Selig：

  1. 如果您已经删除了 Apollo，请重新安装它；否则，请确保您运行的是最新版本。
  2. 点击“我不需要退款”按钮。
  3. 感觉良好，去给自己买点礼物，因为你知道你帮助了一位才华横溢的开发人员（而且是好人）。

这是 Selig 在 Apollo Reddit 子版块上的告别帖子：

表面上说“我想感谢你们所有人”感觉不真诚，但在这种情况下，这显然是正确的。我已经在这个应用程序上工作了 9 年多了，我从来没有感到精疲力尽，我从与如此棒的社区一起公开构建一些东西中获得了如此疯狂的能量和乐趣，你真的不知道如何当你的北极星只是“听听人们在说什么”时，产品开发就变得容易了。 [...]

我对整个过程的展开感到非常心碎，一开始我真的很高兴与 Reddit 交谈，这是他们出于开发者、版主和整个社区的利益而真诚地进行的事情，但正如许多人向我指出的那样，现在很明显这最终不是他们的意图。如果他们想要一种适合每个人的东西，他们只会努力倾听，而不是在定价时不诚实、冷酷和惩罚性的。我对所有像我一样因此突然失去阿波罗的人感到抱歉。我想用这个应用程序做更多的事情！

但是，合理地说，我现在确实感受到了“不要因为结束而哭泣，因为它发生而微笑”的感觉。我在开发 Apollo 的过程中成长了很多，我遇到了很多了不起的人并向他们学习，结识了终生的朋友，参加了多个 WWDC，甚至在一些会议上出现过，并且我开始致力于一个我绝对喜欢的产品和平台9年。这是一次令人难以置信的跑步，对此除了感激之外很难有任何感觉。

除了“我不需要退款”按钮之外，Apollo 的最终版本还有大量奖励内容，包括几十张壁纸和 Selig 的其他应用程序Pixel Pals的一些奖励。我发现塞利格在面对这场灾难时表现出的良好精神令人鼓舞。 （另请参阅：塞利格最近出现在脱口秀节目中。）

entry.title: Mastodon 关于 Threads 的常见问题解答
entry.content:
Mastodon 创始人兼首席执行官 Eugen Rochko：

今天，Meta 推出了名为 Threads 的新微博平台。此次发布值得注意的是，Threads 打算通过使用与 Mastodon 相同的标准协议 ActivityPub 成为去中心化社交网络的一部分。关于 Threads 将会是什么以及它对 Mastodon 意味着什么，有很多猜测。我们根据今天发布的内容汇总了一些最常见的问题和我们的答复。

What strikes me about this FAQ is that nearly every question has no basis in reality. It's calming the irrational fears of people who view Facebook as a corporate bogeyman. Having written quite a bit recently about Threads joining the open fediverse, I can vouch that these fears are real, insofar as people really do think Threads is somehow going to steal their data, or that Facebook is somehow going to show ads to people on Mastodon servers, but those fears have no more basis in reality than worrying about monsters who live under your bed.

Here's the one that really matters:

Will Meta embrace-extend-extinguish the ActivityPub protocol?

There are comparisons to be made between Meta adopting ActivityPub for its new social media platform and Meta adopting XMPP for its Messenger service a decade ago. There was a time when users of Facebook and users of Google Talk were able to chat with each other and with people from self-hosted XMPP servers, before each platform was locked down into the silos we know today. What would stop that from repeating? Well, even if Threads abandoned ActivityPub down the line, where we would end up is exactly where we are now. XMPP did not exist on its own outside of nerd circles, while ActivityPub enjoys the support and brand recognition of Mastodon.

entry.title: Custom Domain Names as Bluesky Handles — Fun Feature, and Now a Business Model
entry.content:
From the official Bluesky (pro tip: rhymes with brewski and Russki ) blog:

We believe that there must be better strategies to sustain social networks that don't require selling user data for ads. Our first step in another direction is paid services, and we're starting with custom domains . While setting up a custom domain to use with Bluesky and the AT Protocol is fairly straightforward, it does require some familiarity with domain registrars and DNS settings. Yet, over 13,000 users have already either repurposed domains they already owned to use as handles, or purchased a domain solely because of Bluesky. Domains have so much potential as a personalized way to customize identities and as a decentralized way to verify reputation that builds off the existing web. For example, US Senators have used the senate.gov domain to verify their identity on Bluesky without our involvement, and a third-party developer built a web extension that checks if websites are linked to an AT Protocol identity. The possibilities are wide in the domain-as-a-handle space.

We're partnering with Namecheap, a popular domain registrar, to offer a service for easy domain purchasing and management. With this, people can set a custom domain as their handle on Bluesky and the AT Protocol in under a few minutes.

Making it a built-in feature and a source of recurring revenue for the Bluesky company — legally, a public benefit corporation — is a great idea. Using a custom domain name as your handle is one of the best features of Bluesky and the AT Protocol, and it really is rather simple. But by building it in as a feature, Bluesky can make it super simple, and remove the possibility of error.

In Bluesky's settings (which are relatively concise), go to “Change Handle” under “Advanced”. Then tap (or click) “I have my own domain.” On the next screen enter the domain name you own and wish to use in the top field, and Bluesky will show you the domain and value to enter at your registrar . I'm using “gruber.foo”, but you can just as easily use a subdomain like “john.gruber.foo”. The Daring Fireball account on Bluesky will be “daringfireball.net” — I could have used “gruber.daringfireball.net” for my personal account. A publication like, say, The New York Times could allow reporters to each have official Bluesky accounts like “ reportername .nytimes.com”. Verification, in a sense, is built in.

Then just go to your domain registrar and create an entry of type “TXT” using the domain and value you copied from the Bluesky app. Wait a few minutes for the change to propagate and your custom domain is now your Bluesky handle. Here's a screenshot from my settings at Google Domains.

entry.summary: Some initial thoughts and observations on Facebook's much-anticipated Twitter rival.
entry.content:
Facebook's much-anticipated Twitter rival Threads — branded “an Instagram app” — is out. Some initial thoughts and observations:

  • The website's home page contains just a link to the apps for iPhone and Android, but you can view the profile pages for users and permalinks for posts (threads?).

  • The iOS app only supports an iPhone layout. I suppose I should not find this surprising, given that 13 years after launching, Instagram's iOS app still doesn't support the iPad natively, but somehow I do find this surprising. What a fucking mystery for the ages it is that Instagram won't make iPad apps.

  • They're going with the “www” prefix on the web, just like Instagram. That feels archaic to me.

  • The website is view-only. You can't log in, post, or reply. No indication whether this is temporary or by design.

  • URLs are similar to Instagram's: domain name + “/t/” + unique post ID. (Where Threads uses a “/t/” (for threads ), Instagram uses a “/p/” (for post , I presume.) For example: https://www.threads.net/t/CuRtcYTNY3J/ . Much better would be a URL format that includes the username of the poster, so you can tell who posted it just by looking at the URL. Example URLs that show attribution:

    Twitter: https://twitter.com/daringfireball/status/1667603292162240512
    Bluesky: https://bsky.app/profile/gruber.foo/post/3jznmowkftf2e
    Mastodon: https://mastodon.social/@daringfireball/110652280163526529

  • Signing in was incredibly easy using my existing Instagram credentials, which were already on my phone because I have Instagram installed. I didn't even need to re-enter my password. Same username, same avatar, and I opted in to following the exact same accounts on Threads that I follow on Instagram.

  • The timeline is algorithmic — it shows you threads both from people you follow and from people you don't. Just after Threads went live to the public, my timeline was almost entirely from accounts I don't follow, seemingly users who've been testing Threads while it was in beta. As I type this sentence a few hours later, however, my timeline is mostly from people I follow, and thus much more enjoyable. But as yet, there's no way to filter your timeline to only show threads from accounts you've chosen to follow.

  • You can search for accounts, but there's no content search (yet?).

  • No hashtags (yet?) either . Good riddance, I say , but I'll bet they're forthcoming.

  • One feature Threads has launched with, though, are quote posts (retweets in Twitter parlance). Bluesky has them too. Quote posts are useful, fun, and central to the way many people use Twitter. And Mastodon doesn't have them — not by omission, but by design. As I've quipped , Bluesky feels like a new service for people who liked what Twitter used to be. Threads feels like that too. Mastodon feels like a service for people who hated Twitter, and nothing exemplifies that more than its lack of quote posting.

  • Posts are limited to 500 characters, which I think is the upper bound for a Twitter-like service.

  • No word about an API yet. I'm not suggesting that Threads might offer an API to enable third-party clients — no way Facebook would do that — but there ought to be a programmatic interface for bots and such if they want to eclipse Twitter. ( Which Zuckerberg is already stating as a goal .)

  • Speaking of Zuck, in addition to being quite active on Threads out of the gate, he posted to Twitter for the first time in 11 years, and it's perfect .

  • Over 5 million people signed up for Threads in the first 4 hours after launch. (There are about 1.2 million active Mastodon users .)

  • No ads yet. If Threads is successful, surely there will be ads. But in the meantime, it makes for a much better experience than Twitter, where the ads are frequent, large, and scammy . (And they soon might start playing sound .)

  • The site/app seems a bit slow/flaky at the moment, but overall is holding up, and still seems faster than Mastodon.

  • Threads is available in over 100 countries, but not yet in the EU, thanks to their draconian and confusing Digital Markets Act . Rather than forcing US and Asian companies to comply with their regulations, the EU seems more likely to be isolating its citizens from the broader world.

  • ActivityPub federation isn't supported yet but is forthcoming. Instagram chief Adam Mosseri posted :

    We're committed to building support for ActivityPub, the protocol behind Mastodon, into this app. We weren't able to finish it for launch given a number of complications that come along with a decentralized network, but it's coming.

    If you're wondering why this matters, here's a reason: you may one day end up leaving Threads, or, hopefully not, end up de-platformed. If that ever happens, you should be able to take your audience with you to another server. Being open can enable that.

I Like Threads's Chances

The overall vibe of Threads is probably not for me. It's not frantic, but it is busy, and very pop-culture-y. If you're the sort of person who wants a quiet timeline comprised only of posts from carefully curated accounts, Threads is not for you, and probably never will be. But the sort of people who like Twitter's “For You” feed and trending topics in the sidebar might find Threads more fun.

So I'm bullish on Threads's chances for long-term success:

  1. The world needs, or at least wants, something like Twitter.
  2. Twitter itself is falling apart under Musk.
  3. Mastodon is inherently too confusing for mass market adoption, and in ways that can't be fixed without some central authority coming in and imposing a solution, which is against the fediverse's ethos. That doesn't mean Mastodon is doomed or bad. Just that it's never going to achieve mainstream popularity.
  4. Bluesky — which is the one I'm rooting for, personally — remains invitation-only as they scale and continue to define their underlying protocol.
  5. All the other Twitter-like upstarts like Post and T2 and whoever else have no traction at all.
  6. Threads starts with 1 billion eligible users, who already have their usernames, and can opt into following the exact same people they follow in Instagram, which is a product that continues to thrive and which people enjoy.
  7. Facebook and Instagram know how to operate at the highest possible scales — both technically and regarding content moderation. Instagram's content moderation record is far from perfect, but content moderation at scale is impossible to do perfectly . Facebook does it better than anyone, and much better than Twitter.

I even like the name “Threads” — it's short, easy to spell, memorable, makes for a clever icon/logo , and even starts with a “T”, reminding people of Twitter. The word tweet has been a nice thing for Twitter to have stumbled onto. (They didn't coin it; Twitterrific did .) Tweet works both as a noun and verb and everyone in the world knows what it means, whether they use Twitter or not. I don't think thread is going to take off as a verb for Threads, but it's a great noun for posts, and it reinforces the notion that you're supposed to engage with posts by replying.

Elsewhere

Casey Newton has an interview with Mosseri at Platformer. Regarding the EU, Mosseri said:

The more pressing concern at the moment is to launch Threads in all the countries where Meta wants to. It won't be available in the European Union to launch as Meta works to ensure that Threads complies with the EU's new data privacy regulations.

“That's just going to take a while, unfortunately — and I'm particularly frustrated about this point, because I've been living outside of the US for a year now,” said Mosseri, who has been working from London. “I've been on a total kick with my teams about stop launching things in only a couple countries, and not in other countries. … But in this case, it was either we wait on the EU, or delay the launch by many, many, many months. And I was worried that our window would close, because timing is important.”

Regarding the opportunity for Threads, as Twitter self destructs, Newton writes:

When the competition is an app where “cisgender” is considered a slur , Threads has an easy time standing out as an oasis of calm and civility.

Mosseri also granted an interview to Alex Heath at The Verge , where he had a thoughtful answer to the question of why Threads is a standalone app:

It was a hugely contentious debate internally. You could be in feed. You could be a separate tab. You could be a separate app. The challenge with text posts in feed is that the post and comment model just fundamentally does not support public discourse as well as the model that Twitter pioneered with tweets and replies. Treating replies as equal as opposed to subordinate somehow just allows for a very different and much more broad range of public conversations.人们确实一直在 Instagram 上发布文字，尽管我们并不一等地支持它，而且我们也在尝试这样做。这很好，但我认为它解决的用例比更广泛的公共讨论要小得多。

周末，埃隆·马斯克限制了用户一天可以阅读的推文数量，他说这是为了防止数据抓取。虽然这一措施影响了所有 Twitter 用户，但 TweetDeck 用户今天报告了一些重大问题，包括通知和整个专栏无法加载。

马斯克最初对经过验证的用户实施了每日 6,000 条帖子的阅读限制，对未经验证的用户实行了 600 条每日帖子的阅读限制。几小时后，他将推文限制分别提高到 10,000 条和 1,000 条。鉴于 TweetDeck 同时通过各个列加载多条推文，读取限制的影响可能会在 TweetDeck 内放大。

不用说，一家主要收入来源是广告的企业竟然会制定速率限制，这是相当疯狂的，更不用说典型用户在大约 20 分钟的浏览中遇到的严格限制了。人们推测，马斯克的想法是，这是促使人们以每月 8 至 11 美元的价格注册 Twitter Blue 的绝招。

马斯克在周末实施的更大、更根本的改变是，除非你登录 Twitter 帐户，否则推文不可见。这破坏了各种各样的事情。一方面，消息应用程序（如苹果的消息）无法再呈现推文的预览卡。言归正传，它破坏了@daringfireball 自动发帖帐户。更有趣的是，正如 Sheldon Chang 所记录的那样，这一变化完全破坏了 Twitter 本身——组装用户时间线提要的 Rube Goldberg 式机器的某些部分本身就受到这些速率限制，因此 Twitter 自行结束了 DDOS。这就像一家汽油公司实行定量配给，导致自己的油罐车车队陷入困境。

从诞生到本周末，Twitter 一直像博客一样，推文都是公开的。您访问推文的 URL，就会看到该推文。现在，它是一个有围墙的花园，就像大多数 Facebook 一样，仅对登录用户开放。我怀疑这一更改也会阻止互联网档案馆缓存推文。那太糟糕了。

entry.title: 衬线之爱
entry.content:
Mark Wilson 在四月份为 Fast Company 撰写的一篇简介中介绍了 LoveFrom Serif 的创建，这是一个新的字体系列，由苹果非凡的 San Francisco 系列背后的许多设计师设计：

Serifs（想想 Times New Roman）反而成为焦点，经过详尽的搜索后，LoveFrom 设计师 Antonio Cavedoni 将巴斯克维尔作为灵感来源。这种字体是每个人都见过的，所以它会很熟悉，甚至是永恒的。但它有足够的表达成分，可以存在于许多环境中。同样具有巨大吸引力的是约翰·巴斯克维尔本人的历史背景。

“约翰·巴斯克维尔作为一个人，作为一个工匠，他的痴迷和性格与我们这些 LoveFrom 的人惊人地相似，”艾夫说。 “这确实以一种非常自然的方式成为了开发我们自己的字体的起点。”

卡维多尼解释说，巴斯克维尔确实很着迷。正如我们在《大地宪章》的故事中所写，巴斯克维尔首先通过“日本”漆器物品赚钱。当他 40 多岁的时候，他有足够的资源去专注于他对文字创作的热情。作为一名训练有素的书法家，他希望提高书籍印刷的质量。他不仅着迷于巴斯克维尔字体的设计，还着迷于各个金属“冲孔”的精心制作，这些金属“冲孔”压紧每个字母以确保印刷清晰。他甚至配制了一种改进的墨水，并了解到他可以将编织纸放入热黄铜圆筒中，使其具有光泽。

一位致力于墨水配方和纸张整理创新的字体设计师——是的，这听起来像是艾维和他的同事们志同道合的想法。

毫不奇怪，史蒂夫·乔布斯的《Make Something Wonderful》的全部内容（无论是网络版还是限量印刷版）都是在 LoveFrom 中排版的。在此之前，我只遇到过小剂量的 LoveFrom Serif，并且通常是在显示尺寸（如LoveFrom 网站的主页）。事实证明，作为长文本界面，它非常好——传统但独特。一般来说，大多数人认为衬线字体更正式，无衬线字体更休闲。 LoveFrom Serif 感觉像是一种友好、情感温暖的衬线，但在形式和结构上没有放弃任何基础。当然是英国人，但不知何故带有一丝加州的欢迎气息。它显然源自 Baskerville，但与 Apple 平台上的同名 Baskerville 相比，它给人一种不同的感觉，特别是在文本大小方面。

卡维多尼本周在旧金山主要公共图书馆发表了题为“意外的巴斯克维尔：塞里夫之爱的故事”的演讲。令我痛苦的是错过了一场看似精彩的演讲，其中有值得注意的嘉宾和历史书籍，但视频录制即将于“今年晚些时候”推出。

后记：我已经在这个链接上坐了几个星期了，部分原因是，好吧，我这样做，但也因为我想让阅读《Make Something Wonderful》的体验安定下来。对我来说，那本书是《LoveFrom》 Serif 真正的首次亮相。如果你想练习一种字体，可以在里面放一本书。在这段时间里，我多次想到我是多么想念迪恩·艾伦，特别是在此，我渴望他对字体和这本书的想法。无数次重读迪恩的《 二十张脸》 ，这是一本非常简洁和引人注目的“可用文本字体的调查”，我想起他在 ITC 巴斯克维尔的条目也指向伊夫斯夫人，祖扎娜·利科在 1996 年的复兴（有那么长吗？我将永远认为《Mrs Eaves》字体是一种“新”字体），迪恩这样描述它：“通过模仿凸版印刷文本中不可预测的形式来复兴巴斯克维尔，这是一项有趣但矫揉造作的实验。”

★
;

entry.summary: 很难不认为 Twitter 失去了优质品牌广告商，并希望快速进军长视频内容，从这种“筒仓”促销中获得的收益比苹果从新发现的观众中获得的收益还要多。
entry.content:
Apple TV，昨天在 Twitter 上：

距离 #Silo 大结局还有 3 天。

这是第一集的全部内容。

嵌入在该推广推文中的是整个系列的首映。 1

就本段而言，抛开围绕 Twitter 的政治，这是一个相当有趣的促销举措。您可以在 Apple TV 应用中免费观看所有 Apple TV+ 原创剧集的首播剧集： 《Silo 》、 《Ted Lasso》 、 《Severance 》、 《The Morning Show》 、 《Hijack 》（伊德里斯·艾尔巴主演的新惊悚片）——所有这些。这是一个显而易见的策略：即使只看其中一部首播，每月只需花费 7 美元即可观看其余节目。任何流媒体服务的最大障碍就是让人们尝试它。每个拥有 iPhone、iPad 或 Mac 的人都已经安装了 Apple 的 TV 应用程序，而且很多人的电视或机顶盒上都已经安装了该应用程序。但苹果并没有从 Twitter 链接到 TV+ 应用程序——他们直接在 Twitter 上分享了整个剧集。不是 YouTube，不是 Facebook。推特。 直到上个月，这在技术上还是不可能的。

但今天要求任何人抛开推特的政治有点像旧的“但除此之外，你觉得这部剧怎么样，林肯夫人？” “ 玩笑。 Twitter 上有一位排名第一的用户，这个用户就是埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk)，随着时间的推移，他的政治和政策的毒性越来越大，而不是越来越小。广告从根本上来说是为了吸引受众而付费，而不是对内容的认可，但在某种程度上它是一种合作伙伴关系。出版商和平台拒绝令人反感的广告，广告商则避开令人反感的平台。 Apple 与 Twitter 的界限在哪里？

不出所料，马斯克似乎对苹果的Silo促销活动感到兴奋，其中包括自定义的hashflag图标。与 MrBeast 一样有影响力的人吉米·唐纳森 (Jimmy Donaldson)回复马斯克：“确实是明智之举，我从来没有听说过这个节目，现在我正在观看第一集并投资，哈哈。”如果你想知道为什么苹果会考虑继续在 Twitter 上做广告，答案是：该平台仍然具有巨大的影响力。

苹果公司在众多媒体上投入了大量的广告费用。但我唯一看到有人问“苹果为什么在那里做广告？”的地方。是推特。很难不认为，Twitter 失去了优质品牌广告商，并希望快速进军长格式视频内容，从这种筒仓促销中获得的收益比苹果从新发现的观众中获得的收益还要多。重要的不是钱（马斯克有很多钱），而是声望（大多数人认为推特已经破产了）。声望是买不来的，苹果公司选择通过这次促销活动在 Twitter 上给予一些声望。苹果继续在 Twitter 上打广告是否令人愤慨？我拒绝。但他们的选择让人感觉有点奇怪，而且有点好奇。

  1. 几周前我开始看Silo ，我非常喜欢它。第一季做得很好，每周都会揭示更多的整体谜团，同时一路上给出一些答案。 Strong premise, good cast, good production values. It's no Severance but it's really good. (I feel the same way about Foundation , but I like Silo better.) It's a good show and I'm glad it's already been renewed for a second season . In some alternate universe, Silo was a show on Netflix, where more people would have seen it but it would have been cancelled nonetheless . ↩︎

Ron Amadeo's Pixel Fold Lasted Four Days
entry.content:
Ron Amadeo, writing for Ars Technica:

I didn't do anything to deserve this. The phone sat on my desk while I wrote about it, and I would occasionally stop to poke the screen, take a screenshot, or open and close it. It was never dropped or exposed to a significant amount of grit, nor had it gone through the years of normal wear and tear that phones are expected to survive. This was the lightest possible usage of a phone, and it still broke.

The flexible OLED screen died after four days. The bottom 10 pixels of the Pixel Fold went dead first, forming a white line of 100 percent brightness pixels that blazed across the bottom of the screen. The entire left half of the foldable display stopped responding to touch, too, and an hour later, a white gradient started growing upward across the display. [...]

Manufacturers keep wanting to brush off the significant durability issues of flexible OLED displays, thinking that if they just shove the devices onto the market, everything will work out. That hasn't been the case, though, and any time you see a foldable phone for sale, you don't have to look far to see reports of dead displays. I'm sure we'll see several reports of broken Pixel Folds once the unit hits the general public.

Earlier today I described the market for foldables as a niche (people willing to spend nearly $2,000) within a niche (people willing to buy any phone that doesn't support using a protective case) within a niche (people who want a foldable phone in the first place). But that's within another level of niche: people who don't care that foldables are relatively fragile.

★

entry.summary: I'd be all in favor of the FTC pursuing and enforcing laws that require *all* subscription services to have clear, discoverable cancellation options online.
entry.content:
Annie Palmer, reporting for CNBC last week :

The Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday sued Amazon, alleging the nation's dominant online retailer intentionally duped millions of consumers into signing up for its mainstay Prime program and “sabotaged” their attempts to cancel.

The agency claims Amazon violated the FTC Act and the Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act by using so-called dark patterns, or deceptive design tactics meant to steer users toward a specific choice, to push consumers to enroll in Prime without their consent.

Some links:

  • The FTC's own announcement , which contains a link to the very heavily redacted complaint . (Apparently the redactions are at Amazon's behest, not the FTC's, but they render at least half of it meaningless.)
  • A Twitter thread from FTC commissioner Lina Khan summarizing the case.
  • The Wall Street Journal's story on the lawsuit , which — shocker, I know — somehow doesn't mention that The Wall Street Journal itself requires subscribers to make a phone call to cancel a digital subscription to the Journal.
  • “ Amazon's Antitrust Paradox ” — Khan's seminal 2017 paper published in The Yale Law Journal.

I find the FTC's case against Amazon to be weak sauce at best, and bordering on frivolous. Their argument that Amazon has made it difficult to cancel a Prime subscription is just wrong. Yes, it's a few more clicks than it takes to sign up for Prime, but I don't think any of those steps are arduous or unnecessary or unfair or confusing. And in the context of Amazon's entire website — infamously sprawling — it's really rather easy to find.

The FTC might have a better case that Amazon has used deceptive dark patterns to get people to sign up for Prime, but I don't find their case compelling. (Note, however, my above remark that their complaint is heavily redacted. Perhaps some of the redactions cover essential evidence.) But it fails the sniff test in one regard: I've never once heard of anyone complaining that they were tricked into a Prime membership that they didn't knowingly sign up for. I've seen people complaining about how hard it is to cancel all sorts of other subscriptions and memberships. Cable TV providers like Comcast make it really hard to cut the cord. Gyms are notorious for requiring you to cancel a membership in person. And The New York Times only recently began allowing subscribers to cancel over the web, rather than calling and talking to a human whose job it is to talk you out of cancelling . Like I mentioned above, The Wall Street Journal still requires this. That should be illegal.

But Amazon Prime? I've never seen anyone complain about this.

It's way easier to cancel a Prime membership than most subscriptions. And most of the steps the FTC delineates are reasonable “Are you sure?” precautions. It's like complaining that it takes a few more steps to empty the Trash in MacOS (or Recycle Bin on Windows) than it does to create a new file or folder — destructive actions should take a few extra steps.

I'd be all in favor of the FTC pursuing and enforcing laws that require all subscription services to have clear, discoverable cancellation options online. In fact, it seems ridiculous that the FTC hasn't already done this. But singling out Amazon only makes sense insofar as that Lina Khan made a name for herself as a critic of the company.

See also: Ben Thompson, today at Stratechery :

This, to my mind, is the chief reason why this complaint rubs me the wrong way: even if there is validity to the FTC's complaints (more on this in a moment), the overall thrust of the Prime value proposition seems overwhelmingly positive for consumers; surely there are plenty of other products and subscriptions that aren't just bad for consumers on the edges but also in their overall value proposition and reason for existing.

entry.summary: The whole point of an open protocol like ActivityPub is that no one can own it.
entry.content:
My brief “ Not That Kind of 'Open' ” piece yesterday struck a chord for some.

Chris Messina :

Not federating is certainly a choice admins can make, but it's unlikely to have an impact considering that Threads is being bootstrapped off the Instagram social graph.

Would you rather keep the fediverse restricted to its current population of ~8M people or scale it to ~2.35B+?

I don't think most Instagram users will even try Threads (or whatever it's going to be called). But a lot might. And “just sign in using your existing Instagram identity” is a powerful enticement. If you already have an Instagram account, you'll be able to jump right in. How to get started with Mastodon (or any of the other ActivityPub “Fediverse” platforms) has been an enormous obstacle to adoption. People find it confusing, and people don't like being confused. “Just use your Instagram identity” is not confusing at all.

I think there are a lot of long-time Mastodon users who like the fact that it isn't gaining mainstream traction, and want to keep it that way. But then don't call it “open”.

Dare Obasanjo :

It's a weird own goal for various Mastodon admins who are running a decentralized social network based on interoperable protocols to pledge that they won't interoperate with services from existing social networks if built on the same open protocols.

It's not even the hypocrisy, it's just dumb and undermines the entire point of interoperable protocols.

The hypocrisy irks me, but I think he's right that it's foolish too. The Mastodon server admins who are preemptively promising to defederate Threads are effectively guaranteeing that users on their instances will be isolated from a potential majority of users on the overall platform.

Dave Winer, at Scripting News :

They will, in an instant, have millions more users than the existing ActivityPub services will, so the question really is — who's being locked out? It was never a good bet that the architecture of ActivityPub would somehow be able to resist Silicon Valley-scale social networks. That doesn't mean there are no answers, just that bluster isn't one of them. You have to think .

But here's some good news. There's no guarantee that Facebook will be successful on terms that matter to them. Unless a half billion people use their service, it's probably not worth continuing, for a company the size of Facebook. Podcasting has withstood countless attacks like this, and has always been left standing as unsullied as ever. But podcasting is “really simple” and the benefit of federation is well known to users . That's been what's kept it from being pwned by bigco's all these years.

I cited email as an example yesterday of big companies running big instances and not extinguishing the openness that made the platform great. Podcasting is maybe an even better example. I don't take podcasting's future for granted, but 20 years in, it's still thriving as an open medium, despite the presence of titanic players like Apple, Amazon, YouTube, and Spotify. Ultimately the involvement of these big companies has made open podcasting far more popular and enduring than I ever would have imagined 20 years ago, because they brought podcasting to the mass market. And there are some roles that we need big centralized players to play even on an open platform. Apple's iTunes podcast directory, for example. Facebook's Threads app could be something akin to Apple Podcasts for Mastodon.

Tristan Louis :

The anti-Meta #Fedipact can only achieve one thing: make sure that #ActivityPub loses to the Bluesky protocol. Is that what people here want?

As an #openweb advocate, I don't.

Meta joining the Fediverse is like AOL joining the internet: something that will bring a mass amount of people in, create some friction, but ultimately make the net better as more people federating on #Mastodon, #kbin, #lemmy, #pixelfed and other parts of the Fediverse make open protocols that much stronger.

Kbin and Lemmy are to Reddit what Mastodon is to Twitter. Unsurprisingly, they're both seeing an infusion of new users this month, but are both still tiny compared to Reddit.

One controversial aspect to this story is that Meta apparently invited the admins from several top Mastodon instances to brief them on their plans , under NDA. Tim Bray :

My take:

  1. The Fedi folks shouldn't have taken the NDA'd meeting. Transparency is essential.
  2. It is not reasonable to expect ethical behaviour from Meta. It should be assumed that that if they can profit by disemboweling the Fediverse, they will.
  3. There is an opportunity to attract some of the ordinary decent humans on Meta because they don't know anything better exists.

I probably wouldn't de-federate. But only by about 51/49.

Of course such a meeting would be under NDA, for now. It's an unreleased and as-yet unannounced product. Meeting with Facebook under NDA isn't ipso facto wrong — although I do think the fact that they were invited shouldn't itself be part of the NDA. Transparency is essential, but transparency can come after Threads is actually announced. The idea that NDAs are inherently nefarious is just conspirational tinfoil-hat nonsense. (Tinfoil hat nonsense is, alas, having a moment .)

On point 2, I'm fine with starting Facebook with two strikes against it. Put them on a short leash. They start fucking around, Mastodon instances should start de-federating from their product. I just don't see why they should be blocked preemptively. The whole point of an open protocol like ActivityPub is that no one can own it. I'll close this post with the same question I did yesterday : Is the goal of the Fediverse to be anti-corporate/anti-commercial, or to be pro-openness? I think openness is the answer. Others clearly disagree.

;
